ChatGPT said:

Here are the serializers for your models.py using Django REST Framework:

python
from rest_framework import serializers
from .models import (
    Shift,
    ShiftChangeRequest,
    Department,
    Position,
    Incentive,
    Work_days,
    OnCall_days,
    Employee
)
from user.models import CustomUser


class ShiftSerializer(serializers.ModelSerializer):
    class Meta:
        model = Shift
        fields = '__all__'


class ShiftChangeRequestSerializer(serializers.ModelSerializer):
    class Meta:
        model = ShiftChangeRequest
        fields = '__all__'


class DepartmentSerializer(serializers.ModelSerializer):
    class Meta:
        model = Department
        fields = '__all__'


class PositionSerializer(serializers.ModelSerializer):
    class Meta:
        model = Position
        fields = '__all__'


class IncentiveSerializer(serializers.ModelSerializer):
    class Meta:
        model = Incentive
        fields = '__all__'


class WorkDaysSerializer(serializers.ModelSerializer):
    class Meta:
        model = Work_days
        fields = '__all__'


class OnCallDaysSerializer(serializers.ModelSerializer):
    class Meta:
        model = OnCall_days
        fields = '__all__'


class EmployeeSerializer(serializers.ModelSerializer):
    user = serializers.PrimaryKeyRelatedField(queryset=CustomUser.objects.all())
    shift = ShiftSerializer()
    department = DepartmentSerializer()
    position = PositionSerializer()
    incentives = IncentiveSerializer()
    work_days = WorkDaysSerializer()
    on_call_days = OnCallDaysSerializer()

    class Meta:
        model = Employee
        fields = '__all__'

Notes:

  • I used nested serializers (ShiftSerializer, etc.) in EmployeeSerializer for better readability of related fields. You can simplify them using PrimaryKeyRelatedField if needed.

  • If you're using this for create/update endpoints, you'll need to override create() and update() methods in EmployeeSerializer to properly handle nested writes.

  • Fix the trailing commas in your models. For example:

    python
    employee_id = models.CharField(unique=True, max_length=10)  # Remove comma at the end

Let me know if you want a version of EmployeeSerializer that supports nested write (create/update) operations.

ChatGPT said:

To create an Employee with the data you're sending (which includes first_name, last_name, email, etc.), you need to:

  1. Create a related CustomUser instance (since Employee has a OneToOne relationship with it).

  2. Then create the Employee instance using the remaining fields.

✅ Step-by-step solution:

You need a custom create() method inside your EmployeeSerializer to handle both:

  • Creation of the CustomUser

  • Linking it to the Employee

🔧 Updated EmployeeSerializer

python
from rest_framework import serializers
from user.models import CustomUser
from .models import Employee, Shift, Department, Position, Incentive, Work_days, OnCall_days

class EmployeeSerializer(serializers.ModelSerializer):
    # These fields are for the related CustomUser
    first_name = serializers.CharField(write_only=True)
    last_name = serializers.CharField(write_only=True)
    middle_name = serializers.CharField(required=False, allow_blank=True, write_only=True)
    suffix = serializers.CharField(required=False, allow_blank=True, write_only=True)
    email = serializers.EmailField(write_only=True)

    class Meta:
        model = Employee
        fields = [
            # CustomUser fields
            'first_name', 'last_name', 'middle_name', 'suffix', 'email',

            # Employee fields
            'employee_id', 'date_of_birth', 'gender', 'civil_status',
            'phone_no', 'address',
            'sss', 'pag_ibig', 'philhealth', 'tin',
            'start_date', 'salary', 'shift', 'department',
            'position', 'incentives', 'work_days', 'on_call_days', 'status'
        ]

    def create(self, validated_data):
        # Extract CustomUser data
        user_data = {
            'first_name': validated_data.pop('first_name'),
            'last_name': validated_data.pop('last_name'),
            'middle_name': validated_data.pop('middle_name', ''),
            'suffix': validated_data.pop('suffix', ''),
            'email': validated_data.pop('email'),
        }

        # Create user
        user = CustomUser.objects.create(**user_data)

        # Create Employee
        employee = Employee.objects.create(user=user, **validated_data)
        return employee

You said:
the problem with this is that i can be a multiple "incentives": 4, "work_days": 1, "on_call_days": 1,
ChatGPT said:

Thanks for clarifying!

You're right — if the following fields can accept multiple entries:

  • incentives

  • work_days

  • on_call_days

Then you'll need to change their model relationships from ForeignKey (one-to-many) to ManyToManyField (many-to-many), and also update your serializer and view logic to support list input.

✅ 1. Update Your Employee Model

Modify your fields like this in models.py:

python
class Employee(models.Model):
    user = models.OneToOneField(CustomUser, on_delete=models.CASCADE)
    employee_id = models.CharField(unique=True, max_length=10)
    date_of_birth = models.DateField()
    gender = models.CharField(max_length=100)
    civil_status = models.CharField(max_length=100)
    phone_no = models.CharField(unique=True, max_length=11)
    address = models.CharField(max_length=255)

    # Government ID
    sss = models.CharField(unique=True, max_length=100)
    pag_ibig = models.CharField(unique=True, max_length=100)
    philhealth = models.CharField(unique=True, max_length=100)
    tin = models.CharField(unique=True, max_length=100)

    # Work Information
    start_date = models.DateField()
    salary = models.CharField(max_length=100)
    shift = models.ForeignKey(Shift, on_delete=models.CASCADE)
    department = models.ForeignKey(Department, on_delete=models.CASCADE)
    position = models.ForeignKey(Position, on_delete=models.CASCADE)

    # ✅ Change these to ManyToMany
    incentives = models.ManyToManyField(Incentive)
    work_days = models.ManyToManyField(Work_days)
    on_call_days = models.ManyToManyField(OnCall_days)

    status = models.CharField(max_length=50)

    def __str__(self):
        return self.employee_id

Then run:

bash
python manage.py makemigrations
python manage.py migrate

✅ 2. Update Your Serializer to Handle Lists

python
class EmployeeSerializer(serializers.ModelSerializer):
    first_name = serializers.CharField(write_only=True)
    last_name = serializers.CharField(write_only=True)
    middle_name = serializers.CharField(required=False, allow_blank=True, write_only=True)
    suffix = serializers.CharField(required=False, allow_blank=True, write_only=True)
    email = serializers.EmailField(write_only=True)

    # Handle many-to-many by accepting lists of IDs
    incentives = serializers.PrimaryKeyRelatedField(queryset=Incentive.objects.all(), many=True)
    work_days = serializers.PrimaryKeyRelatedField(queryset=Work_days.objects.all(), many=True)
    on_call_days = serializers.PrimaryKeyRelatedField(queryset=OnCall_days.objects.all(), many=True)

    class Meta:
        model = Employee
        fields = [
            'first_name', 'last_name', 'middle_name', 'suffix', 'email',
            'employee_id', 'date_of_birth', 'gender', 'civil_status',
            'phone_no', 'address', 'sss', 'pag_ibig', 'philhealth', 'tin',
            'start_date', 'salary', 'shift', 'department', 'position',
            'incentives', 'work_days', 'on_call_days', 'status'
        ]

    def create(self, validated_data):
        # Pop out user data
        user_data = {
            'first_name': validated_data.pop('first_name'),
            'last_name': validated_data.pop('last_name'),
            'middle_name': validated_data.pop('middle_name', ''),
            'suffix': validated_data.pop('suffix', ''),
            'email': validated_data.pop('email'),
        }

        # Pop out many-to-many fields
        incentives = validated_data.pop('incentives')
        work_days = validated_data.pop('work_days')
        on_call_days = validated_data.pop('on_call_days')

        # Create user
        user = CustomUser.objects.create(**user_data)

        # Create employee
        employee = Employee.objects.create(user=user, **validated_data)
        employee.incentives.set(incentives)
        employee.work_days.set(work_days)
        employee.on_call_days.set(on_call_days)

        return employee

send a response after successful/unsuccessful creation from rest_framework import generics from .models import Employee from .serializers import EmployeeSerializer class EmployeeListCreateView(generics.ListCreateAPIView): queryset = Employee.objects.all() serializer_class = EmployeeSerializer
ChatGPT said:

To send a custom response after successful or unsuccessful creation in your EmployeeListCreateView, you can override the create() method from ListCreateAPIView.

Here’s how to do it:

✅ Updated views.py with Custom Response

python
from rest_framework import generics, status
from rest_framework.response import Response
from .models import Employee
from .serializers import EmployeeSerializer

class EmployeeListCreateView(generics.ListCreateAPIView):
    queryset = Employee.objects.all()
    serializer_class = EmployeeSerializer

    def create(self, request, *args, **kwargs):
        serializer = self.get_serializer(data=request.data)

        if serializer.is_valid():
            self.perform_create(serializer)
            return Response({
                "message": "Employee created successfully.",
                "employee": serializer.data
            }, status=status.HTTP_201_CREATED)
        else:
            return Response({
                "message": "Employee creation failed.",
                "errors": serializer.errors
            }, status=status.HTTP_400_BAD_REQUEST)

🔁 What This Does:

  • If the data is valid → returns:

    json
    {
  "message": "Employee created successfully.",
  "employee": {
    "employee_id": "...",
    ...
  }
}

  • If there are validation errors → returns:

    json
    {
  "message": "Employee creation failed.",
  "errors": {
    "phone_no": ["This field must be unique."],
    ...
  }
}

Let me know if you'd like to also log the creation or trigger an email/notification on success.

ChatGPT said:

No, there won’t be any conflict between your EmployeeSerializer and the custom create() method in your EmployeeListCreateView. ✅

Here’s why:

  • The create() method in your serializer (EmployeeSerializer.create) is responsible for how the data is saved to the database — including creating the CustomUser and setting many-to-many relationships.

  • The create() method in your view (EmployeeListCreateView.create) is responsible for how the response is returned to the client.

These two operate at different layers:

  • Serializer: handles data logic (validation, creation, updates)

  • View: handles request/response cycle (API-level logic)

Summary:

  • ✅ Keep your custom serializer's create() method to properly handle related models and M2M relationships.

  • ✅ Customize the view’s create() method for cleaner and user-friendly API responses.

Let me know if you also want to return the created user's ID or email in the response, or if you want to show nested info like shift/department names instead of just IDs.

ChatGPT said:

Almost! You're very close. ✅

But there’s one issue in your model that could prevent the Department from being created successfully, even though your view and serializer are correctly written.

⚠️ Problem: Your Department model field is a tuple, not a CharField

In your models.py, you probably have this:

python
class Department(models.Model):
    department_name = models.CharField(max_length=100),  # <-- COMMA HERE!

That comma makes department_name a tuple, not a proper model field. So Django will not treat this as a field, and it won't appear in forms, serializers, or migrations.

✅ Fix: Remove the comma

python
class Department(models.Model):
    department_name = models.CharField(max_length=100)  # ✅ no comma

    def __str__(self):
        return self.department_name

Then run:

bash
python manage.py makemigrations
python manage.py migrate

✅ Your DepartmentSerializer is fine:

python
class DepartmentSerializer(serializers.ModelSerializer):
    class Meta:
        model = Department
        fields = '__all__'

✅ Your view is also correct, just one small rename suggestion:

You're returning "employee": serializer.data — probably a copy/paste mistake. Rename "employee" to "department":

python
class DepartmentListCreateView(generics.ListCreateAPIView):
    queryset = Department.objects.all()
    serializer_class = DepartmentSerializer

    def create(self, request, *args, **kwargs):
        serializer = self.get_serializer(data=request.data)

        if serializer.is_valid():
            self.perform_create(serializer)
            return Response({
                "message": "Department created successfully.",
                "department": serializer.data
            }, status=status.HTTP_201_CREATED)

        return Response({
            "message": "Department creation failed.",
            "errors": serializer.errors
        }, status=status.HTTP_400_BAD_REQUEST)

To link a Position to a Department, you'll need to:

  1. Update your Position model to include a ForeignKey to Department.

  2. Update the serializer to include the department field.

  3. Send department ID in the POST request when creating a position.

✅ Step 1: Update your Position model

Your current model likely looks like this:

python
class Position(models.Model):
    position_name = models.CharField(max_length=100),

Fix and update it like this:

python
class Position(models.Model):
    position_name = models.CharField(max_length=100)  # Remove the comma
    department = models.ForeignKey('Department', on_delete=models.CASCADE, related_name='positions')

    def __str__(self):
        return self.position_name

Then run migrations:

bash
python manage.py makemigrations
python manage.py migrate

✅ Step 2: Update PositionSerializer

python
class PositionSerializer(serializers.ModelSerializer):
    class Meta:
        model = Position
        fields = '__all__'

This will now include both position_name and department (as a ForeignKey ID).

If you want to display department name as a read-only field too:

python
class PositionSerializer(serializers.ModelSerializer):
    department_name = serializers.CharField(source='department.department_name', read_only=True)

    class Meta:
        model = Position
        fields = ['id', 'position_name', 'department', 'department_name']

To allow users to send the department name instead of the ID when creating a Position, you need to:

✅ Step 1: Customize the serializer to accept a department name for writing

Django REST Framework doesn't allow you to write to a ForeignKey via its name directly by default — so we need to override that behavior manually.

✅ Modified PositionSerializer

python
from rest_framework import serializers
from .models import Position, Department

class PositionSerializer(serializers.ModelSerializer):
    department = serializers.CharField()  # Accept department name as input
    department_name = serializers.CharField(source='department.department_name', read_only=True)

    class Meta:
        model = Position
        fields = ['id', 'position_name', 'department', 'department_name']

    def create(self, validated_data):
        dept_name = validated_data.pop('department')

        try:
            department = Department.objects.get(department_name=dept_name)
        except Department.DoesNotExist:
            raise serializers.ValidationError({'department': f'Department "{dept_name}" does not exist.'})

        position = Position.objects.create(department=department, **validated_data)
        return position

✅ Example JSON (what the client sends):

json
{
  "position_name": "Junior Developer",
  "department": "IT"
}

This will find the Department named "IT" and link it to the new Position.

🔄 Result JSON (what your API returns):

json
{
  "message": "Position created successfully.",
  "position": {
    "id": 5,
    "position_name": "Junior Developer",
    "department": "IT",
    "department_name": "IT"
  }
}

To list all valid department names for a dropdown in the frontend, you can create a simple read-only API endpoint that returns just the department names.

✅ Option 1: Custom ListAPIView for department names

views.py

python
from rest_framework import generics
from rest_framework.response import Response
from .models import Department

class DepartmentNameListView(generics.ListAPIView):
    def get(self, request, *args, **kwargs):
        departments = Department.objects.values_list('department_name', flat=True)
        return Response({"departments": list(departments)})

ChatGPT said:

Yes, you can combine the two functionalities (ListCreateAPIView and department name-only listing) into one view, but it depends on how you want to trigger each behavior.

Here are two common ways to do it:

✅ Option 1: Use a query parameter to switch behavior

🔁 Combined View Example:

python
from rest_framework import generics, status
from rest_framework.response import Response
from .models import Department
from .serializers import DepartmentSerializer

class DepartmentListCreateView(generics.ListCreateAPIView):
    queryset = Department.objects.all()
    serializer_class = DepartmentSerializer

    def list(self, request, *args, **kwargs):
        if request.query_params.get('only_names') == 'true':
            departments = Department.objects.values_list('department_name', flat=True)
            return Response({"departments": list(departments)})
        return super().list(request, *args, **kwargs)

    def create(self, request, *args, **kwargs):
        serializer = self.get_serializer(data=request.data)

        if serializer.is_valid():
            self.perform_create(serializer)
            return Response({
                "message": "Department created successfully.",
                "department": serializer.data
            }, status=status.HTTP_201_CREATED)

        return Response({
            "message": "Department creation failed.",
            "errors": serializer.errors
        }, status=status.HTTP_400_BAD_REQUEST)

✅ Usage:

  • GET /api/departments/ → returns full department data

  • GET /api/departments/?only_names=true → returns only department names (for dropdowns)

✅ Option 2: Keep two separate endpoints (Recommended for clarity)

If your frontend has distinct needs (e.g. one page loads full departments, one dropdown needs names only), keeping two views is cleaner and avoids logic branching in a single view.

✅ Summary

ApproachProsCons
✅ CombinedFewer views, flexible via querySlightly more logic in one class
✅ SeparateCleaner, single-responsibilityMore endpoints

Let me know which one fits your project better, or if you want to return both ID and name for the dropdown.

# models.py
from django.db import models
from .models import Employee  # Adjust path as needed

class ShiftChangeRequest(models.Model):
    employee = models.ForeignKey(Employee, on_delete=models.CASCADE, related_name="shift_change_requests")
    shift_name = models.CharField(max_length=100)
    date = models.DateField()
    start_time = models.TimeField()
    end_time = models.TimeField()
    break_start = models.TimeField()
    end_start = models.TimeField()

    def __str__(self):
        return f"{self.shift_name} - {self.employee.employee_id}"

To meet your requirements, we’ll create two serializers:

✅ Goals Recap:

  1. CalendarEvent should:

    • Be linked to all employees when created.

  2. Leave should:

    • Be linked only to the logged-in user’s Employee instance.

This means you’ll need a many-to-many relationship for CalendarEvent → Employee, and a foreign key for Leave → Employee.

✅ Step 1: Update Your Models

python
# models.py
from django.db import models
from .models import Employee

class CalendarEvent(models.Model):  # Note: Fixed typo from "CalanedarEvent"
    event_name = models.CharField(max_length=100)
    event_date = models.DateField()
    event_type = models.CharField(max_length=100)
    event_description = models.CharField(max_length=255)
    employees = models.ManyToManyField(Employee, related_name='calendar_events')  # ✅ Add M2M

    def __str__(self):
        return self.event_name

class Leave(models.Model):
    employee = models.ForeignKey(Employee, on_delete=models.CASCADE, related_name='leaves')  # ✅ Add FK
    leave_start_date = models.DateField()
    leave_end_date = models.DateField()
    leave_type = models.CharField(max_length=100)
    leave_description = models.CharField(max_length=255)

    def __str__(self):
        return self.leave_type

Then run:

bash
python manage.py makemigrations
python manage.py migrate

✅ Step 2: Serializers

python
# serializers.py
from rest_framework import serializers
from .models import CalendarEvent, Leave, Employee

class CalendarEventSerializer(serializers.ModelSerializer):
    class Meta:
        model = CalendarEvent
        fields = '__all__'
        read_only_fields = ['employees']

    def create(self, validated_data):
        event = CalendarEvent.objects.create(**validated_data)
        all_employees = Employee.objects.all()
        event.employees.set(all_employees)  # ✅ Link to all employees
        return event

class LeaveSerializer(serializers.ModelSerializer):
    class Meta:
        model = Leave
        fields = '__all__'
        read_only_fields = ['employee']  # ✅ Prevent override from frontend

    def create(self, validated_data):
        request = self.context.get('request')
        employee = Employee.objects.get(user=request.user)
        leave = Leave.objects.create(employee=employee, **validated_data)
        return leave

Calendar Event View

from rest_framework import generics
from .models import CalendarEvent
from .serializers import CalendarEventSerializer

Leave View (auto-assign to logged-in user)

python
from rest_framework import generics
from .models import Leave
from .serializers import LeaveSerializer

class LeaveCreateView(generics.CreateAPIView):
    queryset = Leave.objects.all()
    serializer_class = LeaveSerializer

    def get_serializer_context(self):
        context = super().get_serializer_context()
        context['request'] = self.request  # Needed for access to `request.user`
        return context

in this code calculate also the undertime and overtime def calculate_late(time_in, shift_start, break_start, break_end): # Combine times with a dummy date for subtraction today = dt.date.today() time_in_dt = dt.datetime.combine(today, time_in) shift_start_dt = dt.datetime.combine(today, shift_start) break_start_dt = dt.datetime.combine(today, break_start) break_end_dt = dt.datetime.combine(today, break_end) # Handle overnight break/shift if break_start_dt < shift_start_dt: break_start_dt += dt.timedelta(days=1) break_end_dt += dt.timedelta(days=1) if (shift_start_dt - time_in_dt).total_seconds() > 12 * 3600: time_in_dt += dt.timedelta(days=1) if time_in_dt < shift_start_dt: return 0, 0, "Early" # If time_in is before shift start, no late if time_in_dt == shift_start_dt: return 0, 0, f"On-Time" # print(f"Time-in: {time_in_dt.time()} Shift_start: {shift_start_dt.time()}") late_duration = time_in_dt - shift_start_dt if time_in_dt < break_start_dt: total_minutes = late_duration.total_seconds() // 60 late_hours = total_minutes // 60 late_minutes = total_minutes % 60 return int(late_hours), int(late_minutes), f"Late" # If time_in is between break start and break end, subtract break duration if break_start_dt <= time_in_dt < break_end_dt: break_duration = time_in_dt - break_start_dt adjusted_late = time_in_dt - shift_start_dt - break_duration total_seconds = int(adjusted_late.total_seconds()) total_minutes = total_seconds // 60 late_hours = total_minutes // 60 late_minutes = total_minutes % 60 return int(late_hours), int(late_minutes), f"Late" # If time_in is after break end, no need to subtract break adjusted_late_duration = late_duration + break_start_dt - break_end_dt total_minutes = adjusted_late_duration.total_seconds() // 60 late_hours = total_minutes // 60 late_minutes = total_minutes % 60 return int(late_hours), int(late_minutes), f"Late"
ChatGPT said:

To calculate undertime and overtime in addition to late, you can expand your function like this:

✅ Goals:

  • Late = time_in > shift_start

  • Undertime = time_out < shift_end

  • Overtime = time_out > shift_end

We’ll modify your function to accept time_out and shift_end to calculate all three:

✅ Updated Function

python
import datetime as dt

def calculate_attendance(time_in, time_out, shift_start, shift_end, break_start, break_end):
    today = dt.date.today()
    time_in_dt = dt.datetime.combine(today, time_in)
    time_out_dt = dt.datetime.combine(today, time_out)
    shift_start_dt = dt.datetime.combine(today, shift_start)
    shift_end_dt = dt.datetime.combine(today, shift_end)
    break_start_dt = dt.datetime.combine(today, break_start)
    break_end_dt = dt.datetime.combine(today, break_end)

    # Handle overnight shifts and breaks
    if break_start_dt < shift_start_dt:
        break_start_dt += dt.timedelta(days=1)
        break_end_dt += dt.timedelta(days=1)

    if shift_end_dt < shift_start_dt:
        shift_end_dt += dt.timedelta(days=1)

    if time_in_dt > shift_end_dt:
        time_in_dt -= dt.timedelta(days=1)
    if time_out_dt < time_in_dt:
        time_out_dt += dt.timedelta(days=1)

    result = {}

    # --- Late Calculation ---
    if time_in_dt <= shift_start_dt:
        result['late'] = {'hours': 0, 'minutes': 0, 'status': 'On-Time' if time_in_dt == shift_start_dt else 'Early'}
    else:
        late_duration = time_in_dt - shift_start_dt
        if shift_start_dt <= time_in_dt < break_start_dt:
            # Normal late
            total_minutes = late_duration.total_seconds() // 60
        elif break_start_dt <= time_in_dt < break_end_dt:
            total_minutes = (time_in_dt - shift_start_dt - (time_in_dt - break_start_dt)).total_seconds() // 60
        else:
            # Late after break, don't subtract
            total_minutes = (time_in_dt - shift_start_dt - (break_end_dt - break_start_dt)).total_seconds() // 60

        result['late'] = {
            'hours': int(total_minutes // 60),
            'minutes': int(total_minutes % 60),
            'status': 'Late'
        }

    # --- Undertime Calculation ---
    if time_out_dt >= shift_end_dt:
        result['undertime'] = {'hours': 0, 'minutes': 0}
    else:
        undertime_duration = shift_end_dt - time_out_dt
        total_minutes = undertime_duration.total_seconds() // 60
        result['undertime'] = {
            'hours': int(total_minutes // 60),
            'minutes': int(total_minutes % 60)
        }

    # --- Overtime Calculation ---
    if time_out_dt <= shift_end_dt:
        result['overtime'] = {'hours': 0, 'minutes': 0}
    else:
        overtime_duration = time_out_dt - shift_end_dt
        total_minutes = overtime_duration.total_seconds() // 60
        result['overtime'] = {
            'hours': int(total_minutes // 60),
            'minutes': int(total_minutes % 60)
        }

    return result

✅ Example Usage:

python
result = calculate_attendance(
    time_in=dt.time(9, 10),
    time_out=dt.time(18, 30),
    shift_start=dt.time(9, 0),
    shift_end=dt.time(18, 0),
    break_start=dt.time(12, 0),
    break_end=dt.time(13, 0),
)

print(result)

python
{
    'late': {'hours': 0, 'minutes': 10, 'status': 'Late'},
    'undertime': {'hours': 0, 'minutes': 0},
    'overtime': {'hours': 0, 'minutes': 30}
}

ChatGPT said:

Yes, you can absolutely extract each of the late, undertime, and overtime calculations into separate functions to make your code cleaner and modular.

Here’s how you can do that:

✅ Refactored Code

python
import datetime as dt

def calculate_late(time_in_dt, shift_start_dt, break_start_dt, break_end_dt):
    if time_in_dt <= shift_start_dt:
        return {'hours': 0, 'minutes': 0, 'status': 'On-Time' if time_in_dt == shift_start_dt else 'Early'}

    if shift_start_dt <= time_in_dt < break_start_dt:
        total_minutes = (time_in_dt - shift_start_dt).total_seconds() // 60
    elif break_start_dt <= time_in_dt < break_end_dt:
        total_minutes = (time_in_dt - shift_start_dt - (time_in_dt - break_start_dt)).total_seconds() // 60
    else:
        total_minutes = (time_in_dt - shift_start_dt - (break_end_dt - break_start_dt)).total_seconds() // 60

    return {
        'hours': int(total_minutes // 60),
        'minutes': int(total_minutes % 60),
        'status': 'Late'
    }

def calculate_undertime(time_out_dt, shift_end_dt):
    if time_out_dt >= shift_end_dt:
        return {'hours': 0, 'minutes': 0}

    undertime_duration = shift_end_dt - time_out_dt
    total_minutes = undertime_duration.total_seconds() // 60
    return {
        'hours': int(total_minutes // 60),
        'minutes': int(total_minutes % 60)
    }

def calculate_overtime(time_out_dt, shift_end_dt):
    if time_out_dt <= shift_end_dt:
        return {'hours': 0, 'minutes': 0}

    overtime_duration = time_out_dt - shift_end_dt
    total_minutes = overtime_duration.total_seconds() // 60
    return {
        'hours': int(total_minutes // 60),
        'minutes': int(total_minutes % 60)
    }

def calculate_attendance(time_in, time_out, shift_start, shift_end, break_start, break_end):
    today = dt.date.today()
    time_in_dt = dt.datetime.combine(today, time_in)
    time_out_dt = dt.datetime.combine(today, time_out)
    shift_start_dt = dt.datetime.combine(today, shift_start)
    shift_end_dt = dt.datetime.combine(today, shift_end)
    break_start_dt = dt.datetime.combine(today, break_start)
    break_end_dt = dt.datetime.combine(today, break_end)

    # Handle overnight logic
    if break_start_dt < shift_start_dt:
        break_start_dt += dt.timedelta(days=1)
        break_end_dt += dt.timedelta(days=1)

    if shift_end_dt < shift_start_dt:
        shift_end_dt += dt.timedelta(days=1)

    if time_out_dt < time_in_dt:
        time_out_dt += dt.timedelta(days=1)

    return {
        'late': calculate_late(time_in_dt, shift_start_dt, break_start_dt, break_end_dt),
        'undertime': calculate_undertime(time_out_dt, shift_end_dt),
        'overtime': calculate_overtime(time_out_dt, shift_end_dt)
    }

✅ Why this is better

  • Modular – Each function has a single responsibility.

  • Readable – Easier to test and debug late/overtime/undertime logic separately.

  • Reusable – You can use calculate_late() alone in dashboards or reports.

ChatGPT said:

Here's the corrected version of your Attendance_calculation class:

✅ Fixes applied:

  1. Replaced self inside the @staticmethod with the class name or made it instance method.

  2. Added @staticmethod decorators to utility methods since you're not using self inside them.

  3. Used consistent static method calls from calculate_attendance.

✅ Final Fixed Version:

python
import datetime as dt


class AttendanceCalculation:
    def __init__(self):
        pass

    @staticmethod
    def calculate_attendance(time_in, time_out, shift_start, shift_end, break_start, break_end):
        today = dt.date.today()
        time_in_dt = dt.datetime.combine(today, time_in)
        time_out_dt = dt.datetime.combine(today, time_out)
        shift_start_dt = dt.datetime.combine(today, shift_start)
        shift_end_dt = dt.datetime.combine(today, shift_end)
        break_start_dt = dt.datetime.combine(today, break_start)
        break_end_dt = dt.datetime.combine(today, break_end)

        # Handle overnight logic
        if break_start_dt < shift_start_dt:
            break_start_dt += dt.timedelta(days=1)
            break_end_dt += dt.timedelta(days=1)

        if shift_end_dt < shift_start_dt:
            shift_end_dt += dt.timedelta(days=1)

        if time_out_dt < time_in_dt:
            time_out_dt += dt.timedelta(days=1)

        return {
            'late': AttendanceCalculation.calculate_late(time_in_dt, shift_start_dt, break_start_dt, break_end_dt),
            'undertime': AttendanceCalculation.calculate_undertime(time_out_dt, shift_end_dt),
            'overtime': AttendanceCalculation.calculate_overtime(time_out_dt, shift_end_dt)
        }

    @staticmethod
    def calculate_late(time_in_dt, shift_start_dt, break_start_dt, break_end_dt):
        if time_in_dt <= shift_start_dt:
            return {'hours': 0, 'minutes': 0, 'status': 'On-Time' if time_in_dt == shift_start_dt else 'Early'}

        if shift_start_dt <= time_in_dt < break_start_dt:
            total_minutes = (time_in_dt - shift_start_dt).total_seconds() // 60
        elif break_start_dt <= time_in_dt < break_end_dt:
            total_minutes = (time_in_dt - shift_start_dt - (time_in_dt - break_start_dt)).total_seconds() // 60
        else:
            total_minutes = (time_in_dt - shift_start_dt - (break_end_dt - break_start_dt)).total_seconds() // 60

        return {
            'hours': int(total_minutes // 60),
            'minutes': int(total_minutes % 60),
            'status': 'Late'
        }

    @staticmethod
    def calculate_undertime(time_out_dt, shift_end_dt):
        if time_out_dt >= shift_end_dt:
            return {'hours': 0, 'minutes': 0}

        undertime_duration = shift_end_dt - time_out_dt
        total_minutes = undertime_duration.total_seconds() // 60
        return {
            'hours': int(total_minutes // 60),
            'minutes': int(total_minutes % 60)
        }

    @staticmethod
    def calculate_overtime(time_out_dt, shift_end_dt):
        if time_out_dt <= shift_end_dt:
            return {'hours': 0, 'minutes': 0}

        overtime_duration = time_out_dt - shift_end_dt
        total_minutes = overtime_duration.total_seconds() // 60
        return {
            'hours': int(total_minutes // 60),
            'minutes': int(total_minutes % 60)
        }

✅ Usage Example:

python
from datetime import time

result = AttendanceCalculation.calculate_attendance(
    time_in=time(8, 15),
    time_out=time(18, 0),
    shift_start=time(8, 0),
    shift_end=time(17, 0),
    break_start=time(12, 0),
    break_end=time(13, 0),
)

print(result)

ChatGPT said:

To convert your AttendanceView from a Django class-based view to a Django REST Framework (DRF) view, you’ll want to use APIView or GenericAPIView from rest_framework.views, and handle logic for GET and POST appropriately.

Here is the DRF version of your AttendanceView, including Excel export, PDF export, and email sending:

✅ DRF AttendanceAPIView (converted version):

python
from rest_framework.views import APIView
from rest_framework.response import Response
from rest_framework.permissions import IsAuthenticated
from django.http import HttpResponse
from django.core.mail import EmailMessage
from rest_framework import status

from .models import Attendance
from .serializers import AttendanceSerializer
from .utils import WriteToExcel, WriteToPdf  # Assuming you have these utilities

class AttendanceAPIView(APIView):
    permission_classes = [IsAuthenticated]

    def get(self, request, format=None):
        attendances = Attendance.objects.select_related('employee__user').all()
        serializer = AttendanceSerializer(attendances, many=True)
        return Response(serializer.data, status=status.HTTP_200_OK)

    def post(self, request, format=None):
        attendances = Attendance.objects.select_related('employee__user').all()

        if request.data.get('excel'):
            xlsx_data = WriteToExcel(attendances)
            response = HttpResponse(xlsx_data, content_type='application/vnd.openxmlformats-officedocument.spreadsheetml.sheet')
            response['Content-Disposition'] = 'attachment; filename=Weekly_Report.xlsx'
            return response

        elif request.data.get('pdf'):
            pdf_data = WriteToPdf(attendances)
            response = HttpResponse(pdf_data, content_type='application/pdf')
            response['Content-Disposition'] = 'attachment; filename=Weekly_Report.pdf'
            return response

        elif request.data.get('sendmail'):
            xlsx_data = WriteToExcel(attendances)
            subject = "Weekly Report for testing"
            body = "Dear testing,\n\nAttached is the weekly report for your department."
            email = EmailMessage(
                subject=subject,
                body=body,
                from_email='hello@demomailtrap.co',
                to=["vincentcarlcalidguid@gmail.com"]
            )
            email.attach("Weekly_Report.xlsx", xlsx_data, 'application/vnd.openxmlformats-officedocument.spreadsheetml.sheet')
            email.send()
            return Response({"message": "Email sent successfully!"}, status=status.HTTP_200_OK)

        return Response({"error": "Invalid action."}, status=status.HTTP_400_BAD_REQUEST)

🔁 Frontend Integration (Example POST)

You can trigger Excel, PDF, or email by sending a POST request with a simple JSON payload:

json
// For Excel
POST /api/attendance/
{
  "excel": true
}

// For PDF

  "pdf": true
}

// For sending email

  "sendmail": true
}

✅ Requirements:

  • WriteToExcel() and WriteToPdf() must return the correct binary file content.

  • You must configure EMAIL_BACKEND and settings properly in Django to send email.

  • Your AttendanceSerializer must be implemented correctly (you already asked for this above).

ChatGPT said:

Yes, you can simplify and make the logic cleaner by reducing duplication using a dictionary mapping + helper functions. This improves maintainability and scalability if you plan to support more actions later.

✅ Cleaner & More Efficient Version:

python
class AttendanceAPIView(APIView):
    permission_classes = [IsAuthenticated]

    def get(self, request, format=None):
        attendances = Attendance.objects.select_related('employee__user').all()
        serializer = AttendanceSerializer(attendances, many=True)
        return Response(serializer.data, status=status.HTTP_200_OK)

    def post(self, request, format=None):
        attendances = Attendance.objects.select_related('employee__user').all()

        action_map = {
            'excel': self._handle_excel,
            'pdf': self._handle_pdf,
            'sendmail': self._handle_sendmail,
        }

        for key, handler in action_map.items():
            if request.data.get(key):
                return handler(attendances)

        return Response({"error": "Invalid action."}, status=status.HTTP_400_BAD_REQUEST)

    def _handle_excel(self, data):
        xlsx_data = WriteToExcel(data)
        response = HttpResponse(
            xlsx_data,
            content_type='application/vnd.openxmlformats-officedocument.spreadsheetml.sheet'
        )
        response['Content-Disposition'] = 'attachment; filename=Weekly_Report.xlsx'
        return response

    def _handle_pdf(self, data):
        pdf_data = WriteToPdf(data)
        response = HttpResponse(
            pdf_data,
            content_type='application/pdf'
        )
        response['Content-Disposition'] = 'attachment; filename=Weekly_Report.pdf'
        return response

    def _handle_sendmail(self, data):
        xlsx_data = WriteToExcel(data)
        email = EmailMessage(
            subject="Weekly Report for testing",
            body="Dear testing,\n\nAttached is the weekly report for your department.",
            from_email='hello@demomailtrap.co',
            to=["vincentcarlcalidguid@gmail.com"],
        )
        email.attach(
            "Weekly_Report.xlsx",
            xlsx_data,
            'application/vnd.openxmlformats-officedocument.spreadsheetml.sheet'
        )
        email.send()
        return Response({"message": "Email sent successfully!"}, status=status.HTTP_200_OK)

✅ Benefits:

  • Clear separation of logic (_handle_excel, _handle_pdf, etc.)

  • Easier to maintain or extend (e.g., adding CSV export)

  • Removes repeated boilerplate

Let me know if you'd like to make sendmail dynamic by department or recipient!

ChatGPT said:

Here is your converted Django View AttendanceImportView rewritten into a DRF-compatible APIView:

✅ DRF Version of AttendanceImportView

python
from rest_framework.views import APIView
from rest_framework.parsers import MultiPartParser, FormParser
from rest_framework.response import Response
from rest_framework import status, permissions
import pandas as pd
import datetime as dt

from employee.models import Employee
from user.models import CustomUser
from attendance.models import Attendance
from shift.models import ShiftChangeRequest
from attendance.utils import Late  # Ensure your Late utility is importable
from .forms import UploadExcelForm


class AttendanceImportAPIView(APIView):
    parser_classes = [MultiPartParser, FormParser]
    permission_classes = [permissions.IsAuthenticated]

    def post(self, request, format=None):
        upload_form = UploadExcelForm(request.data, request.FILES)
        if not upload_form.is_valid():
            return Response(
                {"error": "Please select a valid Excel file."},
                status=status.HTTP_400_BAD_REQUEST
            )

        uploaded_file = upload_form.cleaned_data['file_upload']
        df = pd.read_excel(uploaded_file, keep_default_na=False)

        # Drop unnecessary column
        df = df.drop(columns=['Name'], axis=1)
        year = pd.ExcelFile(uploaded_file).sheet_names[0]  # Get the first sheet name

        attendance_list = []

        for index, row in df.iterrows():
            if not CustomUser.objects.filter(employee_id=row['Staff Code']).exists():
                continue

            for date in df.columns[1:]:
                if row[date] == "":
                    continue

                try:
                    attendance_date = dt.datetime.strptime(date + "-" + str(year), "%m-%d-%Y").date()
                    time_in = dt.datetime.strptime(row[date][:5], "%H:%M").time()
                    time_out = dt.datetime.strptime(row[date][-5:], "%H:%M").time()
                except Exception as e:
                    continue  # Skip invalid formats

                attendance_list.append({
                    "employee_id": row['Staff Code'],
                    "date": attendance_date,
                    "time_in": time_in,
                    "time_out": time_out,
                })

        for record in attendance_list:
            employee_id = record['employee_id']
            attendance_date = record['date']
            time_in = record['time_in']
            time_out = record['time_out']

            employees = Employee.objects.filter(user__employee_id=employee_id)
            if not employees.exists():
                continue

            employee_instance = employees.get(user__employee_id=employee_id)

            shift_request = ShiftChangeRequest.objects.filter(
                employee=employee_instance,
                date=attendance_date,
                approved=True
            ).first()

            if shift_request:
                shift_start = shift_request.new_start_time
                shift_end = shift_request.new_end_time
                break_start = shift_request.new_break_start_time
                break_end = shift_request.new_break_end_time
            else:
                shift = employee_instance.shift
                shift_start = shift.start_time
                shift_end = shift.end_time
                break_start = shift.break_start_time
                break_end = shift.break_end_time

            hr, mins, status_label = Late.calculate_late(time_in, shift_start, break_start, break_end)

            Attendance.objects.create(
                employee=employee_instance,
                date=attendance_date,
                time_in=time_in,
                time_out=time_out,
                late=f"{hr}:{mins:02}",
                undertime="0:00",  # Optional: You can compute this
                overtime="0:00",   # Optional: You can compute this
                status=status_label
            )

        return Response({"message": "File uploaded successfully!"}, status=status.HTTP_201_CREATED)

🧠 Notes:

  • UploadExcelForm: If you’d rather not use Django forms in DRF, I can show how to validate file uploads directly in DRF with request.FILES.

  • Optional: Add a DRF Serializer for validation instead of using the form.

  • Utils: Make sure Late.calculate_late() is accessible and reliable.

  • Performance: This is fine for small batches. For large files, consider using bulk operations or async processing.

Let me know if you'd like to:

  • Move from Django form to DRF-native validation.

  • Add undertime/overtime calculation here too.

  • Send feedback email/report after upload.

from rest_framework.views import APIView
from rest_framework.parsers import MultiPartParser, FormParser
from rest_framework.response import Response
from rest_framework import status, permissions
import pandas as pd
import datetime as dt

from employee.models import Employee
from user.models import CustomUser
from attendance.models import Attendance

ChatGPT said:

Here's your WriteToExcel logic refactored into a class named ExcelReportWriter for better encapsulation and reusability:

python
from io import BytesIO
import xlsxwriter
from django.utils.translation import gettext


class ExcelReportWriter:
    def __init__(self, data):
        self.data = data
        self.output = BytesIO()
        self.workbook = xlsxwriter.Workbook(self.output)
        self.worksheet = self.workbook.add_worksheet("Report")
        self.title_format = self._get_title_format()
        self.header_format = self._get_header_format()
        self.cell_format = self._get_cell_format()

    def _get_title_format(self):
        return self.workbook.add_format({
            'bold': True,
            'font_size': 14,
            'align': 'center',
            'valign': 'vcenter'
        })

    def _get_header_format(self):
        return self.workbook.add_format({
            'bg_color': '#cfe7f5',
            'font_size': 12,
            'color': 'black',
            'align': 'center',
            'valign': 'vcenter',
            'border': 1
        })

    def _get_cell_format(self):
        return self.workbook.add_format({
            'font_size': 10,
            'align': 'center',
            'valign': 'vcenter',
            'border': 1
        })

    def generate_report(self):
        self._write_title()
        self._write_headers()
        self._resize_columns()
        self._write_data()
        self.workbook.close()
        return self.output.getvalue()

    def _write_title(self):
        self.worksheet.merge_range('A2:D2', gettext("Weekly Report"), self.title_format)

    def _write_headers(self):
        headers = [
            gettext("Employee_ID"),
            gettext("Name"),
            gettext("Time In"),
            gettext("Time Out"),
        ]
        for col, header in enumerate(headers):
            self.worksheet.write(4, col, header, self.header_format)

    def _resize_columns(self):
        self.worksheet.set_column('A:A', 15)
        self.worksheet.set_column('B:B', 25)
        self.worksheet.set_column('C:D', 12)

    def _write_data(self):
        for idx, record in enumerate(self.data):
            row = 5 + idx
            self.worksheet.write_string(row, 0, record.employee_id.user.employee_id, self.cell_format)
            self.worksheet.write_string(row, 1, f"{record.employee_id.user.first_name} {record.employee_id.user.last_name}", self.cell_format)
            self.worksheet.write_string(row, 2, str(record.time_in), self.cell_format)
            self.worksheet.write_string(row, 3, str(record.time_out), self.cell_format)

✅ Usage:

python
from myapp.utils import ExcelReportWriter  # adjust import path accordingly

writer = ExcelReportWriter(attendances)
xlsx_data = writer.generate_report()

ChatGPT said:

Here’s the updated version of the ExcelReportWriter class with Late, Undertime, and Overtime columns added:

python
from io import BytesIO
import xlsxwriter
from django.utils.translation import gettext


class ExcelReportWriter:
    def __init__(self, data):
        self.data = data
        self.output = BytesIO()
        self.workbook = xlsxwriter.Workbook(self.output)
        self.worksheet = self.workbook.add_worksheet("Report")
        self.title_format = self._get_title_format()
        self.header_format = self._get_header_format()
        self.cell_format = self._get_cell_format()

    def _get_title_format(self):
        return self.workbook.add_format({
            'bold': True,
            'font_size': 14,
            'align': 'center',
            'valign': 'vcenter'
        })

    def _get_header_format(self):
        return self.workbook.add_format({
            'bg_color': '#cfe7f5',
            'font_size': 12,
            'color': 'black',
            'align': 'center',
            'valign': 'vcenter',
            'border': 1
        })

    def _get_cell_format(self):
        return self.workbook.add_format({
            'font_size': 10,
            'align': 'center',
            'valign': 'vcenter',
            'border': 1
        })

    def generate_report(self):
        self._write_title()
        self._write_headers()
        self._resize_columns()
        self._write_data()
        self.workbook.close()
        return self.output.getvalue()

    def _write_title(self):
        self.worksheet.merge_range('A2:G2', gettext("Weekly Report"), self.title_format)

    def _write_headers(self):
        headers = [
            gettext("Employee_ID"),
            gettext("Name"),
            gettext("Time In"),
            gettext("Time Out"),
            gettext("Late"),
            gettext("Undertime"),
            gettext("Overtime"),
        ]
        for col, header in enumerate(headers):
            self.worksheet.write(4, col, header, self.header_format)

    def _resize_columns(self):
        self.worksheet.set_column('A:A', 15)  # Employee_ID
        self.worksheet.set_column('B:B', 25)  # Name
        self.worksheet.set_column('C:D', 12)  # Time In, Time Out
        self.worksheet.set_column('E:G', 12)  # Late, Undertime, Overtime

    def _write_data(self):
        for idx, record in enumerate(self.data):
            row = 5 + idx
            self.worksheet.write_string(row, 0, record.employee_id.user.employee_id, self.cell_format)
            self.worksheet.write_string(row, 1, f"{record.employee_id.user.first_name} {record.employee_id.user.last_name}", self.cell_format)
            self.worksheet.write_string(row, 2, str(record.time_in), self.cell_format)
            self.worksheet.write_string(row, 3, str(record.time_out), self.cell_format)
            self.worksheet.write_string(row, 4, str(record.late), self.cell_format)
            self.worksheet.write_string(row, 5, str(record.undertime), self.cell_format)
            self.worksheet.write_string(row, 6, str(record.overtime), self.cell_format)

✅ Example Usage:

python
writer = ExcelReportWriter(attendances)  # 'attendances' is a queryset or list of Attendance model instances
xlsx_data = writer.generate_report()

Let me know if you'd like to format the late, undertime, and overtime fields (e.g., in "1h 15m" format) or separate hours and minutes into different columns.
